speechtext:
Madam Speaker, I am pleased to be able to rise in the House today to represent the Minister of Transport as we begin second reading debate of Bill C-45, an act to promote public safety in the transportation of dangerous goods.
The minister had rather hoped to be here himself for this particular debate, as he has addressed the House previously on the importance of transportation to Canada and the role it plays in our competitiveness and prosperity, and he wanted to extend that debate to this important piece of legislation.
However, he is in Vancouver today, as most members already know, for the signing of an agreement to transfer Vancouver International Airport to a local airport authority. This is a task he completed yesterday in Calgary and in Edmonton with the transfer of those two airports to local authorities.
The minister nonetheless wanted me to convey to the House his appreciation that this debate is going forward today, as it will certainly be of benefit to Canadians to have this bill move expeditiously through the parliamen-taiy process and on to implementation.
Today I am addressing the need to regulate certain transportation activities to promote the safety of people, property and the environment. As we are all aware, our standard of living depends on a sound transportation infrastucture and its ability to move all cargoes safely and efficiently.
The production of many goods we use, whether or not in themselves dangerous in their finished state, may involve the transportation of hazardous products at some time in their manufacture or production. This could include explosives, acids or pressure-liquefied gases.
Our concern, as the Department of Transport, is to ensure that such dangerous goods are transported in a manner which ensures public safety with no undue burden on industry.
In 1980 Parliament passed the first Transportation of Dangerous Goods Act. Ten years of experience with that legislation prompted us to initiate consultations with industry, the provincial governments, interest groups and the general public on possible amendments to the act.
In July 1990 the present Minister of Transport, then minister of state, had 19,000 copies of a discussion paper distributed to industry organizations, provincial governments, federal departments, interest groups and the general public.
That paper contributed significantly to the development of Bill C-45, which is intended to replace the Transportation of Dangerous Goods Act of 1980 with the Transportation of Dangerous Goods Act, 1992.
Transport Canada has maintained an excellent partnership with the provinces in the administration of a single, national dangerous goods program which com-

April 3, 1992
Government Orders
prises federal and provincial legislation and a variety of joint activities.
The primary focus of Bill C-45 is to prevent accidents during the transportation of dangerous goods. It is a realistic bill and takes into account what should happen when, despite everyone's best efforts, accidents occur.
For certain circumstances, it requires that industry establish emergency response assistance plans and file with Transport Canada, for approval, summaries of these plans. A similar provision has been in place for the past several years and I must tell the House that I was extremely impressed when I learned of the excellent work done by Canadian industry associations.
For example, the Canadian Chemical Producers Association has established a national transportation emergency assistance plan that allows a member company to call upon another member company anywhere in Canada to provide assistance at an accident.
I am very pleased to be in a position to advise the House that this made-in-Canada approach, which ensures a very rapid, professional response, has been adopted in the United States and is finding acceptance in several European countries as well.
Bill C-45 will ensure that industry will respond effectively to transportation access. It also provides that any emergency responders such as volunteer fire departments will receive adequate information on the products involved. This happens through the established placarding, labelling, and documentation system.
In addition, Transport Canada will continue to operate the Canadian Transportation Emergency Centre, known throughout the industry as CANUTEC, which operates 24 hours a day to provide information and guidance to whatever technical depth is required by those who are responding to an emergency situation.
Bill C-45 will ensure that, when importers bring into Canada material that is regulated in Canada, they must satisfy our regulations.
Under Bill C-45 Canada's national transportation of dangerous goods program will remain in harmony with international programs such as those of the United Nations, the International Maritime Organization and the International Civil Aviation Organization, as well as those of the United States and other countries.
This will be done to ensure that Canadians will not be placed at a disadvantage in the international market by domestic requirements which either over-regulate or under-regulate transportation activities.
With respect to compliance, Bill C-45 maintains the severity of fines and jail terms provided under the 1980 legislation but two new elements are added.
First, it provides that an offence can be viewed as a new offence on each day it continues. This will ensure that an incentive remains for a company to correct an infraction quickly following its discovery.
Second, the bill allows court orders to be issued to persons convicted under indictment to (a) prohibit the person from engaging in some or all activities regulated by the bill for up to one year, (b) compensate for damages such as to volunteer fire departments for extended supplies, (c) to restore the environment, or (d) require the person to conduct or pay for technical research and development relating to the safe transportation of dangerous goods.
Except for the prohibition to engage in certain activities, the maximum penalty for the remaining three items is not to exceed $1 million per infraction.
I am very pleased with the excellent work and consultations which have led to these improvements to Canada's transportation of dangerous goods program.
I am sure the text merits the attention of all members of Parliament who will recognize the importance of assuring speedy passage and adoption of this bill.

speechtext:
Madam Speaker, I am privileged to rise on debate at second reading of Bill C-45, an act to promote public safety in the transportation of dangerous goods.
As the bill's title indicates, it deals with the transportation of dangerous goods in all modes of transportation, by rail, road, sea or air.
The safe transportation of all types of dangerous goods is of great concern to many people. Canada is a vast nation with hundreds of thousands of hectares of uninhabited land. However, all transportation routes emanate from our cities and towns, and it is especially in these populated areas that extreme care must be given for the proper handling of dangerous noxious substances.
April 3, 1992

Many Canadians, especially those in southern Ontario, do not have to look back too far to recall an event which brought great concern to this important issue of the carriage of dangerous goods.
In 1979, a train derailed in Mississauga. It was carrying chlorine gas. Twenty-four cars of that train derailed at a level crossing at Mavis Road after a journal box responsible for the lubrication of axles overheated and dislodged. Two propane- filled cars exploded into a huge fireball of chlorine gas. Over 225,000 Mississauga residents were forced to leave their homes for several days. That image is burned into my mind because at that time I was a reporter for a local television station in Hamilton. I was assigned the reporting duties of going to Mississauga to cover the accident, what had happened and then the follow-up stories of the evacuation of all those hundreds of thousands of individuals from their homes.
I do not want to have this House think that I draw the following comparisons for partisan reasons. Not at all. I draw the comparison because, like the very motion before this House yesterday dealing with deregulation and safety, all things involved in transportation require, first and foremost, safety. As I stated in this House yesterday, you cannot fudge on safety. The parallels are these.
First of all, like the Diyden crash, the Mississauga train derailment was cause for a judicial inquiry, headed by Samuel Grange. Second, like the Dryden inquiry, the accident was attributed in part to safety standards or the lack thereof relating to inspection and proper maintenance of rolling stock. Like the Dryden inquiry, there were no warning signals. Fortunately though, in the case of the Mississauga train derailment, there were no serious injuries.
In 1970, there were three serious accidents in Ontario which caused much public concern and resulted in public inquiries. The first was a derailment at Cobourg, Ontario, that involved 25 cars. The second was a derailment of 14 cars caused by a plain bearing failure. The third was a collision.
In the 1979 report into the Mississauga train derailment, the commissioner had this to say about the Canadian Transportation Commission, the CTC, now the National Transportation Agency. I quote:
Government Orders
(k) The Question of Funding:
The reason for this inactivity, if such it can called, is twofold. First there is a lack of money and manpower. In this connection a submission has, I understand, gone into Treasury Board seeking provision for more salaries to expand the accident investigation, inspection, planning and standards development programs including the engaging of specially qualified officers to go into shippers and manufacturers' plants and railway yards throughout Canada to ensure compliance with Red Book regulations. I have no knowledge of the priorities and 1 do not wish to intrude upon Treasury Board decisions. But surely at the very least, the CTC should have the funds to find answers not dependent on information or advice supplied by the railways. The railways are answerable to their shareholders; the CTC is answerable to the public.
The other reason is philosophical. It was very clear from the evidence of Mr. David Jones, the former chairman, and Mr. John Gray, the present chairman of the RTC, that there is an ingrained reluctance to take any action involving expenditure or loss to the railways without a complete investigation of the amount of that expenditure or loss and an assurance that the benefit to be gained will fully compensate for that loss-I cannot understand how the Commissioner could leave to the railways the regulation of the speed and length of trains. A long, fast train is a profitable one; it is not necessarily a safe one.
Wise words, Madam Speaker. Does it sound familiar? Dollars versus safety? Guess which one has been winning with this government as of late?
Let us not forget as well that transportation is becoming increasingly intermodal and high-tech. On the roads, tractor trailer trucks sometimes have two full-length cars behind them travelling, some would say, faster than the speed limit. In the U.S., they have triple car trailers behind trucks. Trains carry freight boxes from trucks stacked too high. Cabooses have disappeared, replaced by sophisticated detection devices. All of these factors obviously increase the risk of an accident occurring. So, caution is the watchword.
However, let me go back to my comments to the safety issue. The Brotherhood of Railway Carmen in 1989 stated in a report that fewer inspectors and less stringent inspection could cause another accident involving dangerous goods. They stated in the report that since the 1979 Mississauga accident, 2,000 safety inspectors had been cut by the railways. That is no way to be thinking about safety.
Again, in 1989, this House was concerned with the issue of contaminated fuels entering this country by

April 3, 1992
Government Orders
road. Apparently there were not enough safety inspectors at our borders to deal with the inspection of the transportation of dangerous goods. Perhaps there are alternatives to resource allocation which could keep up with these incidents. Perhaps where centralization is concerned, there could also be a devolution of control. One suggestion put to me just this morning from the mayor of Mississauga, Hazel McAllion, was that safety inspection and related mandatory supervision of dangerous goods transportation could be decentralized.
She said to me on the telephone this morning: "We have an opportunity here to ensure that there are enough inspectors and there is the enforcement of what the inspectors must do in the field. However, the government is going to have to provide all these inspectors and, of course, the related enforcement". In her words: "This is a huge country. We know where the rail lines are; we know where the train travels. We know where the ships are; we can board them and see all their cargo, but what of trucking? We do not know where all the trucks are all the time. There are no specifically designated routes that they always follow". She has seen a bit of a complication here in trying to ensure that there is adequate inspection and enforcement of safety regulations on the industries, on the carriers.
She went so far as to suggest maybe we should decentralize and put the responsibility of inspection and enforcement on the local fire and police departments. I am not saying whether that is right or that is wrong or whether it is a good idea or whether it is not a good idea, but I have got an open mind to these kinds of things.
She does have a caveat, of course. Hazel says: "If we put the whole idea of decentralizing inspection and enforcement into the hands of police departments and fire departments and special units within those units, we had better have the federal funding allocated to them in order to carry out the job". The unfortunate part, and there are complications that you can see immediately in that how do you supervise all of these many different fire departments and police departments to ensure that the job is being done, et cetera. That one idea she came up with indicated again to me the statement she made that this country is huge. There are many modes of transportation. There is considerable transportation of these dangerous and noxious substances.
We could have the best regulations in the world. We could have volumes of material, regulations and rules that say we had better be making sure, if we are to transport these particular substances which are dangerous or noxious, they are contained in this fashion, labelled in this fashion, and transported in that fashion.
However, in order to ensure that is happening, we need the inspectors and then, if there are inconsistencies in the law, there must be enforcement. That is going to take a commitment by this government, a commitment that just yesterday in this House we demonstrated in the airline industry was not there. Why? It was because the government has one agenda, an ideology of economic restraint.
On the other hand, this government preaches at the same time that the need or priority of Transport Canada is safety and that we cannot fudge on it. Unfortunately the two collide. It was stated not only by me and my colleagues in the House yesterday. It was stated by Justice Moshansky in his report. It has been indicated by witnesses to Justice Moshansky and the inquiry that there is a philosophical difference between the two.
There are opinions which we should discuss, and I suggest that among witnesses who will appear before the legislative committee of this House to study this bill are municipal leaders like Hazel McAllion from Mississauga who has extensive knowledge in these areas. We could discuss her ideas further and set them out there.
For example, clause 6 of the bill would require emergency response plans by carriers of dangerous goods in case of an accident. Perhaps through this vehicle carriers of dangerous goods travelling along known routes and alternative routes could, in conjunction with local authorities, put into place such a plan as would be capable of dealing with a disaster should one occur.
Clause 9 of the bill gives powers to inspectors. The minister may invoke or revoke an inspector's licence. The minister may authorize and designate persons to approve emergency response plans or to issue directions or permits for inspectors.
There are many other requirements of inspectors such as obtaining a warrant for a search of a premises for noxious substances, for example, and powers of the minister to follow under this bill. The inspectors will have to comply with a great series of regulations
April 3, 1992

throughout the course of their duties both to ensure safety and respond to an accident.
A new provision would provide that where an inspector believed it was necessary to prevent an accident from happening, he or she could take appropriate measures to prevent harm to the environment, people and property. For the record, and I want to say it again, I have heard the government has consulted widely on this bill and it has support.
As gold plated as this bill is today at second reading before going to committee for full discussion, it will not mean anything to the safety of Canadians or their property or their environment if proper monetary resources are not given for all these safety inspections and the enforcement that may follow.
That is our message. I look forward to following this bill in legislative committee. We will be very attentive to all the witnesses who appear before the committee on it. We will ask the necessary questions including those questions, I hope, to the minister responsible, the Minister of Transport, to assure Canadians just how far this government will go to ensure that the funds are allocated and to ensure that safety and enforcement are truly the priority of this minister, the priority of Transport Canada and the priority of this government.

speechtext:
Madam Speaker, I am pleased to rise today to debate at second reading Bill C-45, an act to promote public safety in the transportation of dangerous goods.
I am pleased that the government has brought forward this legislation. When the original bill was passed in this House a number of years ago, my caucus supported it but also argued that it did not go far enough. Surprise, surprise, I will make the same arguments today.
We support the changes that have been introduced: the clarification of the coverage through a new proclamation certainly giving inspectors greater authority to act in order to prevent injury or damage to people, property and the environment; the requirement that industry must put together response plans; the recall system for containers, transport packages, gas cylinders,
Government Orders
tanks, et cetera; and a wider range of penalties, in fact some innovative penalties that would require someone who is found guilty of a breach of this act actually to spend money to provide the necessary public prevention or clean-up equipment.
I want to outline some of the additional steps we believe the Government of Canada should be taking. A lot of them focus on those men and women who are the front line of defence when there is an accident involving hazardous goods.
I am talking about the emergency response personnel, fire-fighters, police and the medical teams inevitably found at the scene of an accident involving hazardous goods, whether it is road, rail or perhaps even air. They are the first ones there. They are the ones who are responsible for (a) trying to determine what they are dealing with and (b) trying to do something about it either in terms of containment or in terms of control or elimination of the problem.
Fire-fighters are very concerned about the lack of information. This act and its predecessor act require some form of placarding on the equipment. We have all seen the rectangular signs on their edge, but most of us do not know what they mean. The fire-fighters and police are required to know.
I am also told that in the cab of the vehicle or the cab of the train-it used to be the caboose of the train; we do not have those any more-is a manifest outlining the chemicals, the hazardous goods, and how to deal with them. We have seen a number of occasions where the cab has been destroyed and there is no direct access to what is contained in the vehicle that is now leaking or oozing something.
Fire-fighters are proposing a national computerized registry that would be instantly accessible by the emergency response personnel at the site of an accident. That registry would be required to contain all the information about every shipment of hazardous goods moving by whatever mode in this country.
Before shippers could place that material into a transportation vehicle, they would have to register the information with the computer bank. They would also be required to place a unique identifier that directly related

April 3, 1992
Government Orders
to the information placed in the data bank in a number of locations on the vehicle. If there were an accident involving a tank truck or a truck carrying low level or high level nuclear waste or any fuel or hazardous good, the emergency response team would quickly locate the bar code, feed it into the computer, and immediately know not only what was in that truck but would have a print-out as to the action it would have to take.
That action would delineate things like the kind of material to use to extinguish a fire. I am not sure if most people realize that water cannot be used on a lot of these things, that specialized foam materials or other chemicals are used to counter a fire when dealing with hazardous goods, particularly a chemical.
It would also warn the team about the toxicity of what it was dealing with, whether it becomes airborne and therefore whether all emergency personnel have to wear respirators, or whether there is the potential of contamination through the skin and whether or not they would have to wear protective clothing.
Right now we are sending our emergency response personnel into unknown hazardous situations. Quite frankly they do not know. The fire-fighters' association has documented evidence of case after case after case of fire-fighters who have eventually been diagnosed as having cancer that has been related back to a specific fire that they attended to.
We ask these men and women to put their lives on the line every time they leave the fire station, the police station or the hospital to attend to a hazardous goods accident. If we look at the breakdown of line of duty deaths for fire-fighters, we find that nearly 15 per cent are due to burns and asphyxiation, 44 per cent due to heart attack and stroke, 12 per cent due to apparatus failures, and falls by about 12 per cent as well.
Injuries due to exposure to hazardous materials of the non-inhalation kind, in other words contact with the skin, are about 2 per cent of the over-all injuries. To us it does not seem like a very large amount. However, we should think of the kind of long-term damage that can be done by fumes, by contact with cancerous agents in the line of work. It might not show up for a number of years but it can be very deadly. We need to do something about that. If we can put bar codes on every roll of toilet paper it will be very simple for us to have bar codes tied into a computerized system for every vehicle transporting hazardous goods in this country. It is a very simple process.
We have the technology to do it. All we need is the will. Bill C-45 gives us the tool to incorporate that kind of suggestion into the system. It is clearly a question of having the right to know and it will allow fire-fighters and other emergency response personnel to better ensure that public safety is promoted. The clear intent of the title of this bill is the promotion of public safety in the transportation of dangerous goods.
We can make those changes and I certainly will be pursuing that, as my colleagues will in committee.
The other area I would like to briefly mention is what happens to our emergency response personnel in the line of duty. A number of fire-fighters are killed every year in the line of duty. A number of fire-fighters are permanently disabled in the line of duty, and never return to work. The International Association of Fire Fighters has proposed the creation of a one-time compensation benefit paid to the survivors of those killed or permanently disabled in the line of duty. I would like to quote from one of its legislative fact sheets:
Fire fighters and other public safety officers risk their lives daily in an effort to save the lives and property of their fellow citizens. When these brave men and women are killed in the line of duty, as they are with alarming frequency, their deaths are in defence of the citizens of their country, just as surely as a soldier who is struck down by an enemy.
Currently, Canada has no way to acknowledge the supreme sacrifice paid by these heroes who are killed or permanently disabled in service to their country. The only compensation available to them or their families is the benefits normally available to workers injured on the job.
One way for a grateful nation to pay its respect to these brave victims is to provide a one-time compensation benefit to the survivors of those killed or permanently disabled in the line of duty.
I know that we cannot do that within the context of Bill C-45. However I flag it as an issue that I believe the legislative committee should examine and then perhaps provide some guidance to the government.
The other area I want to deal with is infectious disease notification, and I believe we can do that by amending Bill C-45. Exposure to infectious disease is a major reason that fire-fighting is one of the world's most dangerous professions. Fire-fighters and other emergency response personnel routinely provide emergency medical treatment in unsanitary conditions on patients they know nothing about. This results in fire-fighters being
April 3, 1992

occupationally exposed to a variety of dangerous contagious diseases.
Fire-fighters who have been exposed to infectious diseases need to be informed of this fact so that they can seek medical monitoring and modify their behaviour to avoid further transmission.
To address this concern the Government of the United States recently enacted a law requiring that hospitals notify emergency response personnel about the infectious status of patients treated by emergency workers. The law prohibits involuntary testing of patients and only requires the hospital to share any such information in its possession. The program is also structured to protect the confidentiality of patients. It is a balancing act.
Those men and women who are on our front lines when it comes to emergency responses, primarily with regard to the transportation of hazardous goods but also in a broader context, should have the right to know. They should know if they have inadvertently been dealing with someone who has a contagious disease and that they may have been infected either through their pores, through breathing, or other ways.
I would like to see this legislation changed to accommodate that concern so that we can provide them with, not protection but the knowledge of the diseases to which they may have been exposed. In some ways, it is no different than the chemicals which they have been exposed to in the course of their activities.
One of the other areas I want to discuss is the role of Emergency Preparedness Canada. Nothing in this legislation provides an automatic linkage to Emergency Preparedness Canada. It used to be called the Emergency Measures Organization.
In each community it is responsible for disaster plans. Its people are the ones with the expertise. They are the ones who have done the planning to evacuate the Mississaugas, to evacuate parts of Thunder Bay. That is their role. Yet there is nothing in this bill requiring then-notification of any major shipments of hazardous goods coming through their area of jurisdiction. I think it has to be changed to include that notification.
Another area I want to just briefly discuss is the shipment of blood samples. Most communities do not have laboratories to analyze blood. Yet on a daily basis
Government Orders
blood is shipped from community to community to be tested. Most of the blood would not cause any problems if someone were exposed to it, but we do not know.
A lot of this blood, certainly in northwestern Ontario, is being shipped on Greyhound buses in unmarked containers. In the winter it is not shipped in the luggage compartment but is brought inside the bus and put on the racks.
There are no specific controls. This bill needs to address that concern. Workers handle it and passengers may be exposed to it without even knowing it is there. This creates a unique situation.
The other problem is that shippers must be totally responsible. It should not just be the responsibility of the transportation company. There have been situations reported to me in which hazardous goods have been purposefully disguised as something else and transported on a Greyhound bus.
Aerosol paint cans, which have the potential to explode, are regularly being transported on Greyhound buses. That is not Greyhound's fault. It does not and is not required to ask everybody to open their parcels. It is the shipper who has decided to take the cheap route to get product from community A to community B who is violating the spirit of the act. We need to tighten that up as well.
The bill is a good progression but we have additional work to do. Certainly I would hope that in committee we have the opportunity to call the people who I have been talking about, the front line troops who have to handle the hazardous goods after there is an accident, and not just the people from the industry who come in to clean it up with their specific plans of action.
It is the people who are there within minutes of the accident happening who need to know what they are dealing with. Let us hear from them firsthand so that we can get a sense of the changes we need to make to this legislation to make it the best possible legislation to protect the public and the public's employees.

Mr. Speaker, the speech just given by the member from the New Democratic Party was a very enlightening one. It contained a number of ideas. If I were to express myself on this bill with that amount of time I would probably echo a lot of the comments he made.

April 3, 1992
Government Orders
Dangerous goods and the transport of dangerous goods is a concern for all Canadians, more so in some regions than others.
I would like to provide a local riding perspective. There is a chemical plant in my hometown, not more than a quarter of a mile away from my place of residence. At that place, the ICI plant, there is a very professional response team that is very well qualified. In fact, it is recognized as the assigned response team for any accidents in Atlantic Canada and even the eastern part of the province of Quebec. It has responded to a number of train derailments involving chemicals in the provinces of Quebec and New Brunswick.
This is a concern. The member outlined some of the problems these response teams have when they get to that site. I certainly appreciated him mentioning the ideas of bar codes, proper clothing, and whatnot.
My question relates more specifically to the bill with the question of inspections-

As you know, Madam Speaker, the bill authorizes the designation of inspectors whose duties consist of monitoring compliance with the provisions of the act.

I know that the hon. member is quite concerned with transportation and that he participated quite extensively in the debate yesterday on air deregulation. I know that he is quite aware that we are talking about some types of deregulation in the transport industry in all modes.
I am wondering if the member could assist me and members of the House by advising us whether he feels that there is an undertaking by the government to ensure that we have enough inspectors and whether there will be proper training for those inspectors. I would also like him to comment on whether he thinks that the government would provide the money. Yesterday we heard in the debate, time and time again, people questioning whether the government had the commitment to ensure that inspectors were definitely in place.

Madam Speaker, I thank my colleague for his comments and his questions.
In examining the Department of Transport estimates for the current fiscal year it was clear, at least on the rail side, that it had made a conscious decision to increase the level of funding for rail safety and I applaud that. This is not something that people normally expect me to say in this House, but when it does a good thing it should be complimented for it.
However, only time will tell whether the continuing cutbacks by the railroads themselves, as they cut comers and find ways to be more competitive with their competitors in the United States and with trucking, will mean that we will see an increase in accidents in spite of the number of inspectors.
Keep in mind that the railroads themselves have their own inspection crews to monitor the safety of the operations. This has changed from a situation in which an individual would walk the whole length of the train and then the other side to check all the important components to one in which there is a drive-by inspection in which somebody just stands and watches to see if anything is hanging down. The railroads are doing that.
The government inspectors check the inspectors. I do not believe that the system is more safe today than it was 10 years ago, in fact I would suggest the opposite.
Also with regard to the member's comments, there was an article in The Ottawa Citizen on March 16, just a couple of weeks ago, about the closing of a stretch of highway 401 west of Cornwall. It was closed for 13 hours when a cylinder of chemicals fell off a flatbed trailer truck.
The mishap late Saturday afternoon had police and fire-fighters from nearby Ingleside scrambling to prepare for possible explosions and toxic gas leaks. They believed that the 20,000 kilogram cylinder contained highly explosive liquid nitro-oxyacetylene. The Ingleside fire chief, Shaw Lalonde, said that later information revealed that the chemical was in less dangerous gel form. He said that there was mass confusion as to what was in that container and blamed the trouble on incorrect paperwork.
This is a classic example showing that we need bar codes and a national computerized registry so that we do not have this kind of confusion, chaos, and danger.

port. However, I want to point out that a handbook does not tell us what is in that truck if the placards have been destroyed as a result of the accident.
The whole point of my intervention about the computerized registry is to take that book and incorporate that information into it with the addition of any specific updates on specific loads on specific days.

subtopic: TRANSPORTATION OF DANGEROUS GOODS ACT, 1992 MEASURE TO ENACT
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, I am very happy to be able to participate in the debate on this bill. Before I begin I would like to congratulate the administration on a job very well done in addressing some of the issues ignored by the previous bill, the 1980 act.
As well, I want to thank my colleague for Hamilton West who very nicely addressed some of the concerns our party has about this bill.
['Translation\
Finally, this bill identifies nine classes of dangerous goods and regulates their transportation in terms of securing the safety of the public, property and the environment. The nine classes of dangerous goods are as follows: explosives, compressed gases, inflammable liquids, inflammable solids, oxidizing substances, toxic substances, radioactive materials, corrosives and miscellaneous dangerous goods, including environmental pollutants.

This bill attempts to deal with a variety of issues concerning the transportation of dangerous goods from one location to the next. It attempts to strengthen the Transportation of Dangerous Goods Act. It also attempts to provide a clearer legal framework for regulating the transportation of dangerous goods. It seeks to place additional emphasis on taking steps prior to transportation to protect the safety of people, property and environment.
The 1980 act that was in place attempted to bring in partners such as the territorial and provincial governments to set up some standards dealing with the transportation of dangerous goods.

It being 11 o'clock a.m., pursuant to Standing Order 30(5), the House will now proceed to Statements by Members pursuant to Standing Order 31.

Madam Speaker, I promised myself that I would stay clear of the arts this session, but today I am going to break my vow.
In front of the House of Commons today stands on display part of a painting by Ken Kirby called: "Isuma-taq". If those gorgeous people down at the National Gallery could give their heads a shake, this real piece of art could be hanging in the place of "Stripe of Ire with no Voice". Our art gallery could become Canadian again representing this land, true north strong and free.
As I see it Ken Kirby should be given the Order of Canada and "Isumataq" could become the new voice of unity at our National Gallery before it is purchased by the United States of America.

Madam Speaker, I want to bring to the attention of all Canadians the plight of the commercial printing industry in Canada.
Since the free trade agreement came into effect, U.S. customs harassment based on country of origin markings has cost our printers 1,700 jobs and $160 million in lost exports. Since the FTA was implemented, Canada's annual print deficit with the U.S. has reached $330 million. That is a 200 per cent increase since 1988.
Here is the problem in a nutshell. The country of origin marking regulations in the U.S. are far too strict and are not always applied fairly. On the other hand, Canada's regulations need to be tightened to ensure that imported products are properly marked.
Canadian commercial printers want a level playing field with the Americans. They do not have that now. The problem cannot be wished away. It requires government action now.

Madam Speaker, I would like to share with the House some of the advice my constituents are giving me.
Heather and Dennis Sheehan of Caledon East write:
We are optimists. We love Canada. We know we are Canadians. Quebec is very much a part of Canada. We all came here from somewhere else. The more we travel and meet others the more we appreciate what we have here.
Paul Lonergan of Milton writes:
We are certainly creating a debt legacy at every level of government that will stifle and strangle future generations. Governments must begin saying no to social net programs and individuals must be made more responsible for their own welfare.
Finally, Roger Lang of Burlington writes:
I want to see this country be one I can be proud of personally and internationally. We may have family differences but we must rise to a best for all positions rather than repeatedly studying and trying to satisfy every vocal group. We need to change the political system so elected officials work together for Canada rather than trying to make sure they only get re-elected.

Madam Speaker, the UNCED Earth Summit in Brazil in June is an opportunity for Canada and all nations to make a strong commitment to our shared environment and to take real action to protect it. Yet Canada is not standing up for meaningful international agreements on such important issues as global warming.
Instead of putting forward solid proposals to meet its own commitment to reduce the emission of CO2 gases, Canada is asking for credit for tree planting, wanting to deal with the symptoms of the problem rather than deal with the fundamental causes, energy production and use in Canada.
We have joined other nations in blocking a proposal to put environmental controls on international corporations. It is fine to talk about sustainable development, but where was Canada when GAIT decided that environmental protection was not necessarily an acceptable

trade impediment? Where are we in our argument for an integrated environmental-

Madam Speaker, why is the Canadian government rushing to sign away Canadian jobs and sovereignty to Mexico, whose government imprisons its citizens for peacefully demonstrating on behalf of workers and farmers?
Senor Luis Aguilar Salazar was arrested on March 17 during a peaceful protest demonstration. He is a candidate of the opposition PRD for the local congress. He is also a counsellor to the Frente Democratico Campesino, a peasant group supported by Canadian NGOs. He was charged with criminal offences relating to a previous peaceful demonstration of peasants.
He is now known in Mexico as the first political prisoner of the North American free trade agreement because President Salinas fears public demonstrations.
I call on the Prime Minister to demand that President Salinas release Senor Aguilar Salazar and stop the police from harassing critics of the government.

Madam Speaker, the most recent report from Statistics Canada is critical of the increase in service charges, which have tripled service charge revenues in chartered banks since 1980.
My constituent, A1 Deruiter, owner of the Port Col-borne Catering and Vending Company, will not be surprised at this. Mr. Deruiter, quite rightly, objects to paying $2.15 per $100 for rolled and counted coins when sorted currency is $1.40 per $1,000. He now has an added cost of $150 a month, a cost he can ill afford.
Service charges are destroying relations between business and bankers at a time when the business community should be working together. I plead with the Minister of Consumer and Corporate Affairs to consider this matter seriously and to take appropriate action.

subtopic: GENERAL AGREEMENT ON TARIFFS AND TRADE
GENERAL AGREEMENT ON TARIFFS AND TRADE
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, yet another deadline is going to pass and the Uruguay round of GATT negotiations will remain unresolved. I urge the government to keep maximum pressure on GATT participants to stress the importance of strengthening and clarifying article XI.
The Prime Minister is obliged to personally explain Canada's balance position to President Bush, but this has yet to happen. Meanwhile, the anxiousness of Canadian farmers in the agrifood industry is increasing. This uncertainty must not continue, as the cost is too great. I urge the government to get the job done.
April 3, 1992

Madam Speaker, the announcement by the U.S. pasta company Borden Catel-li Ltd. that it will close its plant in Winnipeg is more bad news for the food processing industry in Manitoba.
What is more frustrating about this closure is that it could have been avoided. Other groups, including the employees, have indicated they would buy the factory and keep the plant working. However, Catelli refuses to sell the plant. Instead, the factory will be stripped, the empty building will be sold and the jobs will be lost.
The attitude of this American company is disgraceful. It shows what little loyalty American companies have to Canadian workers and for the communities that are devastated by such arrogant moves.
The provincial Conservative government is standing aside and doing nothing for Manitoba on this issue. What will it take for the Conservatives to stand up for the farm families and the workers? If a U.S. company will not maintain a Canadian factory, it should be required to sell to those who are willing to buy it. If the Conservatives will not support Manitoba workers, they should hand over the government to somebody who will.

Madam Speaker, I rise today to bring to the attention of Parliament a matter that is of great concern to many Canadians and citizens of other countries, namely the intention of the government to further weaken its position of respect in the world by pulling out more peacekeeping troops from NATO.
There are press reports citing a spokesperson for the Secretary of State for External Affairs stating the opinion that the Canadian peacekeeping troops in Cyprus should be removed since, and I quote: "There doesn't seem to be much progress nor effort at times being spent by the parties concerned to come to a resolution". I
would like to ask the minister on what facts she bases this assertion or lack of effort on in light of previous assurances that the government was not planning to remove the troops from Cyprus.
I would like to know what has changed. Canada's commitment to ensuring a peaceful settlement of the dispute in Cyprus must not be weakened by shortsighted cost-saving measures.

Madam Speaker, I want to congratulate Veterans Affairs on the television ad it has produced to commemorate the 75th anniversary of Vimy Ridge. Veterans in my riding have often complained that Canadians are not taught enough about our own history. They say that our kids know more about American victories than our own.
That is why it is so refreshing to see us telling the story of one of the greatest victories in our history. Seventy-five years ago this week the Canadian Corps succeeded where other armies had failed and showed the world what a young country called Canada could accomplish.
I am also delighted that Canadians will also have the chance to learn more about the Dieppe raid. Fifty years ago this year Canadians were chosen to test Hitler's Fortress Europe and, like the Canadian Corps at Vimy, our forces responded with great courage and discipline.
These campaigns have left us with an enduring lesson for, as the commercial says about the Vimy victory, "This is the spirit of Canadians working together".

speakerposition: Deputy House Leader of the Official Opposition; Liberal Party Deputy House Leader
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, this government is about to embark on yet another silly, expensive and wrong-headed crossborder shopping trip. Some months ago, the government announced that it was tendering for the construction of the space agency in Montreal. Railtech Ltd., a manufacturer in my riding, was pleased that it was going to have
April 3, 1992

an opportunity to bid for the curtain walls of the space agency. However, it now appears that the government will award the $1.5 million contract for curtain walls to a U.S. supplier. Worse yet, it is not reciprocal. Similar products made by Railtech cannot be used in many contracts for rail cars in the United States, for instance, because of a "Buy American" policy that many cities and state jurisdictions have.
This government has to answer why it is continuously exporting Canadian jobs south of the border.

Madam Speaker, last week I had the privilege as a parliamentarian, representing Parliamentarians for Global Action, to attend a meeting in Italy on a proposal to create an international criminal court. Members of the International Law Commission of the United Nations, distinguished diplomats, expert law professors from all over the world, including Professor Sharon Williams of Canada and Cherif Bassiouni of the United States, legal advisers and judges put forward a proposal for an international criminal court and a model international criminal code to go with it. Surely this is an idea whose time has come.
Take the current problem of the Libyan nationals accused of blowing up western airliners, including the Pan Am jet over Lockerbie, Scotland. Clearly, there is some doubt whether the Libyans could get a fair trial in Libya and Libya is reluctant to surrender them to a U.K. or a U.S. court. The solution is a world criminal court.
Take the case of international drug dealers, genocide or criminal environmental acts like what we saw during the gulf war, cases again for such a court.
Madam Speaker, I call on the House to urge the Government of Canada to support at the United Nations Sixth Committee this fall the proposal for an international criminal court, an idea whose time has come.

I congratulate the leaders of various merchant navy organizations and associations for winning what had been a long and frustrating fight for equal status.

In November we had another instance of veterans winning a lengthy fight when Korean war veterans belatedly received a Canadian Volunteer Service Medal. Just like the merchant mariners, the Korean veterans had been turned down by government after government. In contrast, this government and this Minister of Veterans Affairs find solutions, not excuses. I wish to congratulate him.

speakeroldname: Mr. Peter Milliken (Kingston and the Islands):
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, last week the Department of National Defence announced that it will consolidate armed forces supply depot operations by moving the Toronto and Moncton depots to Montreal.
In February 1990 a private research consultant was paid by the Department of National Defence to examine depot consolidation. This study, which examined operational costs, freight distribution costs, real estate values and construction costs concluded that both the Montreal and Toronto depots should be closed down and I quote: "The site for the new facility should be within the proximity of the city of Kingston, Ontario".
What is the point in paying private research consultants to carry out detailed technical evaluations of military operations when their recommendations are ignored for political purposes? What is the point in arguing that the government and national defence are doing all they can to be cost effective when ministers can override decisions which save Canadians millions?

April 3, 1992
Oral Questions
Canadians are demanding cost effective, efficient government. Instead, all they get from this group is empty rhetoric, broken promises and patronage for Tory fat cats.

Madam Speaker, my question is for the minister of fisheries concerning the so-called offers made by the European Community yesterday on overfishing.
We know the minister has characterized these offers as an insult and a political gimmick. The bottom line is, these are not offers. They are a slap in the face to Canadian fishermen. We know the minister can deliver on rhetoric.
What we would like to know today is what action he specifically intends to take to tell these Europeans that these offers are a joke and that we want real action.

speakeroldname: Hon. John C. Crosbie (Minister of Fisheries and Oceans and Minister for the Atlantic Canada Opportunities Agency):
speakerposition: Minister for the purposes of the Atlantic Canada Opportunities Agency Act; Minister of Fisheries and Oceans
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, we have received no offer from the European Community as yet. There are reports in the newspapers that the commissioner for fisheries is to suggest to the ministers of fisheries of the European Community, who are meeting, that some kind of an offer be made to Canada, that they would reduce by some percentage their quota for northern cod.
Since they have no proper quota for northern cod outside 200 miles, since they are ignoring a moratorium with respect to cod that was imposed by NAFO, the international body for the area that manages fisheries matters, and they have been ignoring that since 1986, we can hardly be impressed by their suggestion that they would reduce their quota.
In addition, the facts are that on March 16 the European Community issued a report with respect to surveillance and enforcement of their own European Community waters and they frankly admitted that they are unable to enforce their own rules in their own European Community waters. If they are unable to enforce the rules on Spain and Portugal in their own community waters, what must the situation be with respect to surveillance and enforcement outside 200 miles?
Such an offer is obviously not one that we are interested in. Number one, they have no quota to offer us to reduce and number two, they have no powers of surveillance and enforcement over Spain and Portugal. This is not anything in which anyone is going to be fooled.
With respect to action-
Time.

speakerposition: Minister for the purposes of the Atlantic Canada Opportunities Agency Act; Minister of Fisheries and Oceans
speechtext: Well, I will get to action if the hon. lady ever gets to a sensible question.

Madam Speaker, the minister may sit there as a puffed up sculpin, which is about the level of his reaction to date. I want to ask him this question. He has just made the case very specifically for Canadians to take custodial management of our own waters and the nose and tail of the Grand Banks.
Given the minister's vicious attack on the plan yesterday, which we in fact agreed with, given his assessment of the non-offers by the Europeans, will he today declare custodial management over the nose and tail of the Grand Banks?

speakeroldname: Hon. John C. Crosbie (Minister of Fisheries and Oceans and Minister for the Atlantic Canada Opportunities Agency):
speakerposition: Minister for the purposes of the Atlantic Canada Opportunities Agency Act; Minister of Fisheries and Oceans
speechtext: Madam Speaker, I would prefer to be a sculpin than a blow-fish.
Oh, oh.

speakerposition: Deputy Speaker and Chair of Committees of the Whole of the House of Commons
speechtext: The hon. minister.

speakerposition: Minister for the purposes of the Atlantic Canada Opportunities Agency Act; Minister of Fisheries and Oceans
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, the first thing I do in the mornings is not necessarily read Jeffrey Simpson. That is something I would rather do in the evenings so that I have time to contemplate the points that are being made.
I will just give you some idea of the action being taken. For two weeks now we have invited and arranged for European journalists to visit Newfoundland to see for themselves the effects of the actions of the European Community with respect to our fishing industry.
April 3, 1992

We are pressing in New York our resolution with respect to the rights of the coastal state to manage straddling stocks.
This week we had Premier Wells down there as a witness. We are quite willing to use anyone at all who is interested in this issue to make our point, so we are pressing this resolution before international bodies. We are continuing our diplomatic approaches in various capitals.
The Prime Minister himself will be taking this matter up with Mr. Delors, the president of the European Community on April 23 when he meets President Mitterrand and other leaders of the European Community. There is a very vigorous campaign under way in connection with this issue.
We first have to persuade the rest of the world that it would be right for us to extend fishery jurisdiction before we take that step, because at the present time the rest of the world does not recognize the rights of anyone to manage fishery resources beyond the 200-mile economic zone provided for in the Law of the Sea Convention.

Madam Speaker, I am sure the Prime Minister will be happy to know that the minister would rather be a sculpin than a blow-fish.
Since 1986 the Europeans have ignored a moratorium on fishing. They have ignored international law. They have ignored NAFO. Once again, in the House today, we heard the minister saying he wants to talk this thing through diplomatically.
Has he not understood, by the results of these insulting offers, that the time for talk is ended, the time for action is now and we, as Canadians, must extend custodial management over the nose and tail of the Grand Banks today?

speakeroldname: Hon. John C. Crosbie (Minister of Fisheries and Oceans and Minister for the Atlantic Canada Opportunities Agency):
speakerposition: Minister for the purposes of the Atlantic Canada Opportunities Agency Act; Minister of Fisheries and Oceans
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, I am very pleased to

hear the hon. member say that she is against rhetoric, but she should certainly start to apply it to herself.
With reference to this situation, we are proceeding by diplomatic means to try to settle this issue, which is the normal way that civilized countries, particularly of the democratic persuasion, proceed.
If using diplomacy bilaterally and multilaterally in every way that we can, we still fail to achieve our objective then we will have to consider whether some kind of unilateral action will have to be taken or not. At that stage, we would want to have the majority of the world's countries support what we are doing in the realization that we have made every other possible effort to solve this situation by peaceful and diplomatic processes.
Canada is a country that believes in peacekeeping. Canada is not a country that believes in the use of violence and force. We are not trying to settle this matter-
Who said violence?

speechtext:
Well, if we say that we have a management regime beyond 200 miles and we tell some country that it cannot fish or it can only catch a certain amount of fish beyond the 200 miles because that is our management regime and it says we do not recognize it what is the next step?
Everything the hon. member says is replete with the use of the threat of force if other countries do not accept our management regime. Let us be sensible, drop the rhetoric. Let us get on with the kind of campaign that we are waging. If that fails to be successful-

speechtext: I think we should go on.

Madam Speaker, my question is also for the Minister of Fisheries and Oceans. I would preface it by saying that surely by this time he should realize that his approach has failed. When is the government going to do something about it?
I want to also say, with great regret, that the mishandling of the fishery on the east coast is now being repeated on the west coast. I have correspondence from Canadian officials to their U.S. counterparts on the Fraser panel which says that the U.S. quota this year should be
360,000	fish. The U.S. response is that it intends to authorize 870,000 salmon being caught, a clear repudiation of its obligations under the salmon treaty.

April 3, 1992
Oral Questions
I want to ask the minister this question. Considering the important loss this will represent to the west coast fishery, why is the minister and this government allowing the U.S. to repudiate its U.S. treaty obligations? Why is it allowing the U.S. to overfish the west coast salmon stocks?

speakeroldname: Hon. John C. Crosbie (Minister of Fisheries and Oceans and Minister for the Atlantic Canada Opportunities Agency):
speakerposition: Minister for the purposes of the Atlantic Canada Opportunities Agency Act; Minister of Fisheries and Oceans
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, one listens to these questions with incredulity.
We are said to be allowing the U.S. to do this and allowing the U.S. to do that. Surely the United States does not seek the permission of other countries when it decides whether it is going to observe a treaty or violate a treaty, so we are not allowing the U.S. to do anything.
In fact, we are disagreeing with the U.S. forcefully with respect to its suggested attitude to the Pacific salmon treaty. That treaty clearly states that the U.S. catch of Fraser River sockeye is to be capped at seven million between 1989 and 1992. The treaty says that the catch includes Fraser River sockeye wherever they are caught, including Fraser bound sockeye caught in Alaskan waters.
The United States wishes to make a change now. It says it does not intend to include Fraser River bound sockeye which were harvested in Alaskan waters over the past three years as part of the seven million allocation. That would obviously be a breach of this treaty and we are strenuously objecting.
We will take what action is necessary to counteract it if the United States attempts to do that. We are not allowing the Americans to do this. The opposition is not allowing it. The opposition's rhetoric is really veiy, very careless.

Madam Speaker, the minister is certainly right when he says he is not a blow-fish.
He is a head-waiter to other countries, simply allowing them to break their treaty obligations and to go ahead and unilaterally assert their right to overfish the Pacific salmon fishery.
I want to ask the minister a question. If the government is so intent on asserting its rights, will the minister undertake direct representation to his counterpart in Washington? Will he be calling in the U.S. ambassador?
Will he be taking action at the ministerial level in order to ensure that the fishing season which starts in a matter of weeks will not find itself with the Americans putting the boots to Canadian fisheries like he has done on the east coast?

speakeroldname: Hon. John C. Crosbie (Minister of Fisheries and Oceans and Minister for the Atlantic Canada Opportunities Agency):
speakerposition: Minister for the purposes of the Atlantic Canada Opportunities Agency Act; Minister of Fisheries and Oceans
speechtext:
The hon. gentleman reminds me of a puff-fish, not a blow-fish.
With respect to this question, this is a matter that we are taking up with the United States, using the usual means by which one takes up matters with neighbours and friends and those who one has treaties with.
We are making it very clear to the United States that it has left only 360,000 sockeye if it observes the provisions of this treaty. That is our position, and we continue to put that to the United States.
It is deplorable that the Americans do not seem to want to observe obligations that they enter into solemnly. This is not something that has happened in connection with the salmon treaty, but that does not mean to say that one cuts off all relationships with the United States.
We have to remind ourselves that it is the market for 75 per cent of our exports, no matter how much the hon. gentleman from Winnipeg huffs and puffs. The way he huffs and puffs, the only house he is going to blow down is his own.

Madam Speaker, my question is for the Minister for International Trade.
This week a delegation of New Democratic members of Parliament, at their own expense, met in Washington with American government and industry officials regarding softwood lumber.
They were there, of course, because thousands of jobs are at stake and are being threatened by U.S. harassment on the softwood lumber issue.
What this delegation found was that the U.S. government and the industry are really demanding the wholesale export of raw logs from Canada into the United States. The wholesale export of raw logs means the export of Canadian jobs.
April 3, 1992

My question for the minister is this. What has the Canadian government done to make it very clear that we will not accept this demand, and that we will not accept free trade in logs?

speakeroldname: Hon. Michael Wilson (Minister of Industry, Science and Technology and Minister for International Trade):
speakerposition: Minister for International Trade; Minister of Industry, Science and Technology
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, what we have done on the broad softwood lumber issue is to take the Americans to the GATT on three issues related to the softwood lumber issue.
We have also vigorously challenged the countervailing duty action, working with the provinces and with the industry as it relates to the injection of the log export controls as a countervailable subsidy.
We have objected strenuously to the U.S. administration and pointed out to them that in 1983 and in 1986 there was no suggestion that log export controls were a countervailable subsidy. In this case they brought this in and we are pointing out to them that it looks to us that they want to see a result at the end and they are using all means to arrive at that end result.
What is most ridiculous about the position of the Americans on this is that they have log export controls themselves. We are pointing out that discrepancy between the two positions they have taken.
I think the leader of the New Democratic Party can be absolutely sure that we are taking the strongest possible action that we can to fight this one.

Madam Speaker, the minister of course is quite right when he says that the American federal government has its own ban on the export of raw logs. But it seems clear both through the industry and through the Bush administration's initiated action on softwood lumber that they are trying to use the fact that certain provinces have a ban on the export of raw logs as constituting an effective subsidy.
I am pleased that the minister says he is fighting this vigorously but this is a very serious issue. It does affect Canadian jobs and Canadian sovereignty. Americans are protecting American sovereignty and American jobs.
Oral Questions
The minister says he is standing up for Canadians on this particular issue but what action is he prepared to take to ensure that Canada's position is put forward very forcefully on behalf of Canadians?

speakeroldname: Hon. Michael Wilson (Minister of Industry, Science and Technology and Minister for International Trade):
speakerposition: Minister for International Trade; Minister of Industry, Science and Technology
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, I do not understand the question. I just stated what the actions were. If my hon. friend has any further suggestions based on her colleagues' trip to Washington, let her put forward those proposals.
In the GATT there are the actions we are taking against the countervailing duty action by the United States.
There is also the promotion campaign we have in the United States ensuring that Americans understand the result of this countervailing action that it is causing an increase in the price of lumber. It is causing an increase in the price of houses at a time when they are trying to get the U.S. economy going.
What I said when I commented on this in Atlanta a couple of weeks ago was that the Americans are shooting themselves in the foot with the actions they have taken.

Madam Speaker, the minister is aware I am sure that there is a very strong feeling both in the government administration and in the industry that the wholesale exportation of raw logs from Canada is the ultimate aim.
Certainly both of those groups told our delegation very clearly that, even if Canada were to win in this particular dispute this time, in two years they would continue the harassment on this because that is the ultimate aim.
It is a question of whether we Canadians can have control over our own economy to build up the secondary industry that we have to do. It is absolutely essential that the government assure every Canadian that we are not going to export our jobs and that we will have an economic strategy that means there will be Canadian jobs and secondary industry in this country.

speakerposition: Minister for International Trade; Minister of Industry, Science and Technology

Madam Speaker, I appreciate the words of support that the hon. member is providing for the positions we are taking.

April 3, 1992

It is precisely because we wanted to have that sovereign control over the management of our forest industry that we took the decision to terminate the memorandum of understanding, I should say strictly according to its terms.
We are in full agreement with the sentiments she is expressing. We are working closely with the provinces and the industry to put forward the strongest possible case. I say to her again, if she has any suggestions as to how we can strengthen our case, I would welcome them.

Madam Speaker, my question is for the Minister of Fisheries and Oceans.
He has reacted to the European Community suggestion that cod quotas should be cut as a political gesture with the words insult, provocation and subterfuge. Those are tough words. The question is: Why is the minister not acting as tough?
If he says we have to be civilized little Canadians going on negotiating for years and years, I remind him that Iceland, one of the oldest democracies in the world and hardly a warmonger, asserted its rights when diplomacy failed.
Why is he on behalf of the Government of Canada not willing to assert similar rights for Canadian fishermen?

speakeroldname: Hon. John C. Crosbie (Minister of Fisheries and Oceans and Minister for the Atlantic Canada Opportunities Agency):
speakerposition: Minister for the purposes of the Atlantic Canada Opportunities Agency Act; Minister of Fisheries and Oceans
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, the rhetoric is certainly flowing strongly this morning.
With respect to the way of proceeding, I believe in the old adage, speak softly and carry a big stick.
Where is the big stick?

speakerposition: Minister for the purposes of the Atlantic Canada Opportunities Agency Act; Minister of Fisheries and Oceans
speechtext: Well, the big stick will be produced when speaking softly no longer works.
It is not working John.

speakerposition: Minister for the purposes of the Atlantic Canada Opportunities Agency Act; Minister of Fisheries and Oceans
speechtext:
With reference to the hon. gentleman's question, what course of action is he suggesting we adopt that we are not adopting now?
We have a resolution before the United Nations Conference on Environmental Development which, by the way, originated in a meeting we called in St. John's, Newfoundland two years ago to start this process. We have convinced 40 other countries to associate themselves with this resolution that would resolve the problem.
We have been dealing with the European Community on a diplomatic level for several years. The Prime Minister is going to carry on intensive discussions of this issue with leaders of the various European Community countries. We have had the foreign media over to Newfoundland to see with their own eyes what the situation is so they can explain it at home.
This is the course of action we are on. What is wrong with our course of action? What more does the hon. gentleman think we can do at the moment?

Madam Speaker, it is very clear that the course of action is not working. It has not worked and is obviously not going to work.
What I fail to understand is that the way he talks is not in the character of the minister. He is not that kind of person. Why does he not admit now, the same as Iceland did, that diplomacy has not worked, is not going to work and we must take unilateral action to assert the rights of our people now.
The difference between us and him is that he feels at some point in the future we have to take action. We say take it now.

speakeroldname: Hon. John C. Crosbie (Minister of Fisheries and Oceans and Minister for the Atlantic Canada Opportunities Agency):

speechtext:

1,800,000	tonnes of codfish from the northwest Atlantic.

April 3, 1992

give the European Community the right to fish within our 200-mile limit. That did not expire until 1986.
When they were in power they were not the powerful tigers, the ferocious, violent desperadoes they want to say that we should be, now that we are in power. When they were in power they did not act in the way they are now advising us to act.
We are pursuing diplomacy' and as long as the diplomatic efforts have a chance to succeed, that is the route we are going. Canadians are not a people who resort to force and violence. We are peacekeepers and that is the course we are going to continue on.

Madam Speaker, my question is for the Minister for International Trade. I want to ask the minister about these trade wars that Canada is losing.
Canadian-made computers have become the latest target of U.S. protectionism. The Canada-U.S. Free Trade Agreement was supposed to protect these industries, but instead they continually find themselves in trade disputes.

speakeroldname: Hon. Michael Wilson (Minister of Industry, Science and Technology and Minister for International Trade):
speakerposition: Minister for International Trade; Minister of Industry, Science and Technology
speechtext:

We rejected it at the negotiating table. At the meetings next week when I will be meeting with my counterpart from the United States I propose to reiterate that rejection. It is something we do not accept.

Oral Questions
When will the minister wake up to the reality that Canadians do not have faith in him to protect then-interests in international trade? When will he take some real action against the Americans on these issues?

That is one example, that I spell out in detail, of how we have protected the interests of Canadians and particularly the interests in his community. We are continuing to fight these battles whether it is in softwood lumber, whether it is in Honda, whether it is in magnesium, whatever the actions are.
I just point out to my hon. friend when you have the largest single bilateral trading relationship in the world, you do have these disputes. What we do have now that we did not have before in the free trade agreement is a dispute settlement panel which makes binding decisions which have affected Canada very positively.

Madam Speaker, Friday is fish day so I would like to go back to the Minister of Fisheries and Oceans.

speakerposition: Minister for the purposes of the Atlantic Canada Opportunities Agency Act; Minister of Fisheries and Oceans
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, with respect to this question, when we started pressing the European Community in January 1989, after the half-sacked report of that year in connection with this matter, their first line of

April 3, 1992
Oral Questions
defence was that these were findings by Canadian scientists not necessarily agreed to by the European Community scientists. Therefore, we said that was fine.
All that information is available to the NAFO scientists. We are making it available to the European Community scientists. We have made all of our information fully available to the scientists of the European Community.
We have just had Ambassador Gherson and the chief of our science branch visit the European Community, Spain, Portugal and the United Kingdom to go over all of this material and evidence with them.
This is simply an excuse dredged up by the European Community suggesting that there should now be a meeting of the NAFO scientific committee. The NAFO scientific committee will be meeting in any event and we will be there.
All of our information is available to anyone that wants it. We have not had any disagreement from European Community scientists with respect to our information. There has been no disagreement in the last several years. So this is just an attempt to confuse the issue.
The evidence is plain. Last year we had a quota of
190.000	tonnes for northern cod and we could only catch
127.000	tonnes. Who needs more evidence, scientific or otherwise, than the fact that the fish are not there to be caught?

Madam Speaker, the minister's last statement indicates we are out of fish. Yet the European Community seems to be catching more than its quota every year which would seem to indicate their stocks are in good shape.
In any case, I wanted to ask a question of the minister. There has been a lot of talk. He spoke on March 30, as reported in Hansard at page 9017, about other methods and he has been talking about that today. Before we get into those other methods, could the minister tell us what is the level of support we are getting in NAFO itself?

Are there any members of the European Community that will support us in this fight before we have to resort to these other methods?

speakeroldname: Hon. John C. Crosbie (Minister of Fisheries and Oceans and Minister for the Atlantic Canada Opportunities Agency):
speakerposition: Minister for the purposes of the Atlantic Canada Opportunities Agency Act; Minister of Fisheries and Oceans

The one exception is the European Community, has refused, ever since Spain and Portugal joined the European Community in 1986, to accept the decisions of NAFO with respect to the northern cod and with respect to certain flounder, redfish stocks, and American plaice. The other countries involved have been supportive of conservation measures and of NAFO decisions. That is the position up to the moment.
With respect to the other members of the European Community, I have to report frankly that we have not received any enthusiastic support from them. I have visited the United Kingdom, for example, France and Germany. Their ministers are sympathetic when we are there but they never take any steps at the internal meetings of the European Community to raise this question or to put pressure on Spain and Portugal to stop these practices.
That is why we are asking them now at the very top, that is when the Prime Minister meets with them, to put pressure on Spain and Portugal to act like civilized countries and not despoilers of the environment and destroyers of certain animal species that are going to disappear if their actions do not cease.
