subtopic: TRANSPORTATION OF DANGEROUS GOODS ACT, 1991 MEASURE TO ENACT
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, as you will probably recall, about 11.55 a.m. I was addressing this issue. I started by congratulating the minister and his staff as well as the administration for their work on this piece of legislation which is, in fact, fairly similar to the act which was introduced in 1980, with quite a few exceptions and a few new proposals.
Government Orders
What really intrigues me with this bill is the fact that it addresses two partners, the provincial government and the federal government. Throughout this bill there is one partner missing, the municipal government or regional government.
When we are dealing with questions affecting the environment, this particular issue falls under the jurisdiction of three levels of government, the federal government, the provincial government and the municipal government, the community as a whole. This piece of legislation does not seem to put it in black and white that a third partner is included.
There are some very good aspects of the proposed legislation, especially when we look at the areas of safety requirements, standard marks, emergency response assistance plans and means of containment. For example, this bill would make it an offence for a person to handle, offer for transport, transport or import any dangerous goods unless the person, the goods and the means of containment satisfy the requirements of the bill.
The bill introduces a concept of a standardized means of containment. This particular term would be defined to mean a container for which safety standards have been prescribed in the regulations and which was used or intended to be used for the transportation of dangerous goods.
It goes on to say that no person would be permitted to sell, offer for sale, deliver, distribute, import or use a standardized means of containment unless it displayed all the applicable prescribed safety marks.
That is good, but it goes further to add a new provision which would require manufacturers or importers of standardized means of containment to keep records of the persons to whom they distributed their product. If it were later found that these means of containment were unsafe for handling or transporting dangerous goods, suppliers could be required to issue notices of defective construction or recall to their customers.
These are excellent proposals in the legislation. What is missing, unfortunately, is the third partner, the municipal government, as it deals with the question of transport.

April 3, 1992
Government Orders
One other aspect which I found to be intriguing is that while there are a lot of new provisions, when it comes to the area of inspection whereby we are giving the inspectors authority, rightly so, when they believe there are reasonable grounds that dangerous goods are being handled, offered for transport or transported in a way that does not comply with the bill, they could detain the goods until they were in compliance, it also gives the inspector the authority to take any measures necessary to remedy non-compliance and allow them to direct any qualified person to take them. That is good, but what is missing is the enforcement, to provide the necessary funds for inspectors in order to apply the rules as set by the legislation.
For any piece of legislation or any proposal, it does not matter whether it is introduced at the federal level, provincial level or municipal level, the key is to have the mechanism for enforcement. That brings us to the human aspect. We have to ensure that we not only have enough inspectors, but that we have the tools that are necessary so they can do their jobs properly.
What has been lacking throughout this whole discussion is the matter of the necessary funds in order to make sure that the bill is enforced and inspectors are capable of doing their jobs.
I do not know how many more inspectors the government is planning to hire. I do not know whether it has thought about that aspect of the legislation. I do not know whether the government has gone as far as trying to do some work with the different levels of government in terms of their enforcement in the difficulties they are having.
I can tell you on the question of environmental impact, the transfer or transport of dangerous goods from one location to another has been identified as a priority for the people of this country. In particular, it has been identified as a priority for the people in my riding of Ottawa Centre and throughout the province of Ontario. I say this because unfortunately quite often what we are seeing is that the transportation method, whether that is by truck or train, is passing through urban centres without making sure that certain provisions and requirements are met. When it comes to that, it is extremely important, at least at the municipal level, to be aware of what is at stake for employees in terms of the transportation of dangerous material going through that particular city, town or area.
Setting up standards is a key when it comes to the environment. If there is any need for national standards, I would say that the environmental needs are there. This should in fact serve as a notice. As we are introducing the Transportation of Dangerous Goods Act, perhaps the federal government should use this as a first step toward negotiation with all levels of government with a view to setting up standards when it comes to the environment.
The reason I say this is because as you go from one part of the country to the next, there are different environmental standards. For instance, what is a priority for one region when it comes to the cleaning up of the environment or taking care of dangerous goods in one area might not be treated the same way in other parts of the country or in other areas.
Environmental standards are very important, especially at this point in time. In 1988 and thereafter there has been a lot of talk about the clean up of dangerous material from major urban centres throughout Canada. I have not yet really seen any direct action taken. I have not seen the results. If there has been any work on the part of the government, any government, we have not seen any impact study to show that. In fact, if we have cleaned up our urban centres of hazardous material, we have simply moved the waste material that could be stored from one part of the country or another.
To that extent, it is high time for the federal government to start discussion with different levels of government, provincial and municipal, in order to deal with the question of stored dangerous materials, especially in major urban centres, in order to set up a strategy where this material could be moved to another location where the safety of the public as well as the safety of the environment would not be at stake.
The question of enforcement is important. Far more important than the question of enforcement is the question of prevention. As you know, our legislation at the federal level, the provincial level or the municipal level seems at all times to deal with the problem at hand. Unfortunately, we do not seem to see a lot of legislation at the different levels dealing with the question of prevention. When we talk about the question of prevention, we are talking about the questions of education,
April 3, 1992

public awareness, and outreach programs. Whether that is at the high school level, whether that is in the community, in the business sector or in different parts of society, we have to take an aggressive step and move one step further to say that from now on every single piece of legislation that is introduced to deal with every single issue has got to have as part and parcel of it a preventive measure.
That would apply to any kind of legislation, whether the legislation is dealing with the question of the environment, or whatever. It must contain that element, the issue of education and the issue of prevention.
I spoke a little bit about the absence of the third component. A little earlier today my colleague from Ottawa-Vanier brought to my attention a very important issue. Probably in the period of question and answer he will be very much interested in sharing his concerns, not only with this House but also with Canadians across the country, to give an example of what is happening in one of the ridings in the Ottawa-Carleton region.
There are a lot of good things in this legislation. What is missing, as I indicated, are the questions of enforcement, outreach, prevention and education. When I spoke about enforcement I mean the lack of funds in order to do the actual enforcement.
I understand that the government is planning after second reading to have a public hearing. This would be an excellent opportunity for all of us in government, as well as the community as a whole, to bring forward to the committee during those hearings any concerns they might have regarding the transfer of dangerous material and the transfer of waste from one point to the next.
At hand here is a piece of legislation that, in my view, is a good start, the beginning I hope of what might lead to a discussion with the different levels of government whereby eventually we would have a national environmental standard throughout Canada so that we can protect the interests of the public and deal with the question of safety in a tangible and effective way.

Madam Speaker, I rise to participate in this debate on the second reading of Bill C-45, an act to promote public safety in the transportation of dangerous goods. As the House will know, this bill seeks to bring into legislation a number of important ideas and recommendations. As far as it goes, it does have my support and the support of our party, as our critic in the area has already explained.
I wish to make a couple of comments if I can arising out of an interest in the issue on the west coast of Canada. A couple of years ago public attention was drawn to the fact that dangerous goods were often transmitted on B.C. ferries and that they were being transmitted without adequate inspection, supervision or compliance with the regulations. In that context, therefore, we had a very careful look at the situation. It became very clear that it is all very well to have a good piece of legislation or to have good regulations, but it is even more important to have adequate personnel provided by the Government of Canada to ensure that the act and the regulations are complied with.
Government Orders
There is still no report back to this House about the situation on the B.C. ferries, and in particular whether the government has acted on the public concern expressed at the time to see that the regulations are complied with and the public is being protected. We will look forward to hearing at committee state from the minister and from the department on this issue and trying to get some commitment from the government that it will couple with this legislation adequate resources and adequate staff to see that the public is in fact protected and that Bill C-45 is not simply words and window dressing.
The next contribution I would like to make deals with a couple of the inadequacies of the bill, particularly because the bill fails to reflect the very effective representations that have been made to all members of Parliament by the International Association of Fire Fighters. In particular is the proposition that there should be included in federal legislation the creation of a public safety officers benefit which should be indexed and payable to the survivors of fire-fighters who are killed in the line of duty, or to the family of an officer who is permanently and totally disabled in the line of duty.
Second is the requirement that hospitals should be given a mandate to notify emergency response personnel of possible exposure to infectious diseases. Third is the need to create a computerized response information system so that fire-fighters can have access to accurate and instant information at the scene of a hazardous materials incident.
These provisions should be in the bill. The government should advise the House and the public how come it was left out. On the face of it, these very important concepts and provisions should be reflected in the bill. They are already reflected in the private member's bill of the member for Port Moody-Coquitlam, and it is important these ideas get the full consideration of the House.
With those comments we will certainly support second reading so that this bill can go before the committee in the hope that at that stage we can get the necessary improvements.

speechtext:
Madam Speaker, I am pleased to participate in the debate for a few minutes. I want to raise two or three items that will be of particular concern to all members,

April 3, 1992
Government Orders
to the industry and to all workers involved in the shipment of hazardous products. These items will undoubtedly arise during the course of committee consideration.
I just preface with a few general remarks on the bill. The bill before us, the Transport of Dangerous Goods Act, 1992 is a redrafted version of the current Transportation of Dangerous Goods Act. The stated purpose of the bill is to promote the safety of people, property and the environment during the transportation of dangerous goods.
Among other items that the bill addresses are the handling, transporting and importing of dangerous goods, safety marks, safety requirements and safety standards, emergency response assistance plans, regulation of standardized means of containment, financial responsibility, actions during emergency response and inspection and intervention authorities of federal inspectors.
Bill C-45 would strengthen the Transportation of Dangerous Goods Act. We fully admit that, and we are pleased to see some progress made.
It would provide a clear legal framework for regulating the transportation of dangerous goods. It would place additional emphasis on measures which would have to be taken prior to the transportation activity itself in order to protect the safety of people, property and the environment.
In addressing the last point mentioned, I would just like to comment briefly on the matter raised under section 6 of the inspector's guide to the Transportation of Dangerous Goods Act, 1992.
Section 6 reads:
Some dangerous goods involved in an accident may continue to cause harm or hold the potential for harm after the initial accident has occurred. For example, a tank car containing a compressed or flammable gas may be in such a position or circumstance that there is concern about the tank itself rupturing and causing a secondary accident effect. For some special dangerous goods, as described in Schedule XII of the Regulations, emergency response assistance plans must be in place before these products are shipped. Essentially this places a burden on the consignor of a product to be prepared to respond in case there is an accident with this product.
This burden falls upon the consignor, who is often the manufacturer, as he is the person who is the expert with respect to the characteristics of the product and he is the person who should know what is required to effectively respond to such an accident. If the consignor is not in Canada, the importer is essentially viewed as
the consignor. (This principle holds throughout the Act such that anything which occurred or should have occurred outside of Canada is the responsibility of the importer. Note that this provides for better protection and enforcement than dealing with an agent. Consequently the requirements concerning agents have been deleted.)
Our major concern here is covered in the next one to two paragraphs:
The way this section will work is that when someone wishes to ship a Schedule XII substance he will submit a summary of an emergency response assistance plan and will "immediately" receive temporary approval. Once the plan has been examined carefully by a Remedial Measures Specialist and found to be acceptable the approval will continue. If the plan turns out to be unacceptable, approval of the plan would then be cancelled and the result would be that the shipper would have to cease shipping that dangerous good.
That particular paragraph gives us some cause for concern. It appears from this documentation that immediate temporary approval will be given to the transport of Schedule XII goods, the most hazardous products, before careful examination by a remedial measures specialist.
If the intent of this is, and it is made clear that it is simply to give preliminary approval, the actual shipment cannot take place until the careful examination, that may be well and good. It will be of little consolation to safety personnel or to communities through which hazardous products are shipped if the turnaround in the decision and the cancellation of the shipping takes place after an accident has occurred because those goods are already in shipment.
Obviously that is one of the areas that we want to look at carefully during committee consideration, to ensure that the immediate approval that is given only gives rise to prior clearance and not to shipping itself until there has been, as it is put here, a careful examination of the conditions.
There are a number of other concerns that have been mentioned briefly by my colleagues which I would also like to touch on.
In my own constituency of Kootenay West-Revels-toke we do have a large number of very hazardous goods in transit. Our area is mountainous. Whether those goods are travelling by truck or by rail, and most of them are shipped on one of those two mediums, we have some of the more difficult stretches of rail in the country and certainly many of the steepest grades in the highway system.
April 3, 1992

What we have seen partly through the policies of this federal government when it comes to transport regulations and legislation is an increasing use of our highways by heavy transport trucks, often on steep grades into urban areas. Many of them carry dangerous goods such as chlorine gas in large quantities.
Rail is a relatively safer means of transport. It is more controllable because there is no competing, generally speaking, on the roadbeds with passenger traffic which is much more unpredictable in its behaviour. The conditions of the roadways and the highways are also very often much more hazardous than is the condition that exists on rail. The abandonment of many spur lines serving industrial areas has caused this transference away from rail and on to the roads.
We have had a number of incidents. Luckily there were no major releases of substances which would cause a grave and immediate health hazard to civilian populations. But we have had a number of serious accidents involving trucks carrying industrial materials, some of them safety related, right into the communities of Trail and Castlegar.
Because we have had a bit of a propensity in times past we have also had situations where we have had not accidental explosions take place from time to time on some of the rail lines in our area. These often caused disruptions to major industrial transport by rail and by truck. That is something we hope to never see repeated. But we do have the problem taking place on the highways with increasing incidence.
One of the other matters that my colleague, the member for Kootenay East, raised yesterday in consideration of another subject is also of concern on this matter. That is the change that has taken place in the railway industry, with the elimination of cabooses to getting rid of flashing lights or strobe lights at the end of trains and their replacement by reflectors. Some of those trains transport dangerous goods.
One may wonder what this has direct relevance to in relation to this bill. If we have an increasing number of accidents-and that is almost surely going to happen as a
Government Orders
result of the relaxation of some of these regulations in transport-then the incidence of releases of hazardous materials into fast-flowing waterways in the mountains of British Columbia is surely going to occur.
If there are reflectors instead of flashing strobe lights on the ends of trains, which ends of trains are no longer manned by individuals who can give constant reports back and forth between units, then in a mountainous area where there are not only steep grades but also a great amount of cloud, fog, mud, snow and curves, there is simply no opportunity to respond. Long braking distances are required on steep grades if there is no clear sign from the end of the train that it has come to a halt or slowed down in order to apply the brakes to avoid a major collision.
Those are in areas again that where those railway carriers are carrying hazardous products and there are releases in the fast-flowing waterways, the damage is done before any emergency response team can get to it.
Those matters are relevant even though they are not directly involved in the consideration of the bill before us.
Finally, I would like to touch once more upon the matter of the submission made to a number of my colleagues, both in the New Democratic Party and I am sure in other caucuses last May by the International Association of Fire Fighters.
Their appeal links in to some degree with a study, the "Electronic Waybill for Rail Transport of Dangerous Goods," which was prepared for the Transportation Development Centre, policy and co-ordination, Transport Canada by ATG, Automation Technologies Group Ltd., and submitted in August 1991.
That system primarily would provide for electronic monitoring of hazardous products and the shipment of hazardous products in a computerized system. That is vital in this day and age with large amounts of very dangerous goods being shipped so that communities, the officials responsible for the permits and the emergency response teams including fire-fighters, will know at a moment's notice just what they have to deal with and how they should deal with it.

Government Orders
A submission was made by the International Association of Fire Fighters to us last year. My colleague, the member for Mission-Coquitlam, has a private member's bill dealing with this topic and perhaps that could, because it is directly relevant to the government bill before us, be considered in some detail when we get into committee.
Just as a background the fire-fighters entitled their proposal "Right to Know". They point out:
The most dangerous aspect of fire fighting is responding to incidents involving hazardous materials. Fire-fighters in Canada are especially hampered by a lack of information available at such incidents. Accurate, accessible information is crucial to saving lives and property at the scene of these incidents since the appropriate response for one hazardous material could prove catastrophic if another substance is present.
A variety of technologically advanced systems are available which would enable fire-fighters to learn the exact nature of hazardous materials present at any location and provide guidance on responding to the specific incident. Such systems can be designed for both hazardous materials at stationary structures and hazardous materials in transit.
Information provided by such systems not only aids in identifying what hazardous materials are present, but also offer detailed information on appropriate emergency response techniques. Some systems can even provide guidance on evacuating specific communities.
Implementation of a hazardous materials identification system would ensure that the fire-fighters have the information they need to effectively respond to any incident enabling them to protect lives, property, and the environment.
The IAFF supports the creation of a computerized national emergency response information system which would enable firefighters to obtain accurate, instant information at the scene of a hazardous materials incident.
I would just say by way of analogy, and I am not suggesting it is quite as simple, but the same principle applies. If supermarkets can use computers to scan for price and inventory purposes, surely it is not too much to expect that that same kind of technology transmitted to a national level be used in order that fire-fighters and their emergency response crews and communities could do the same for their purposes.
That seems to me a rather minimal objective. The technology is now available. The government has some good major studies now at its disposal. There are further studies along these lines being done in the republic to
the south that we can fit in on an international basis to ensure that the very best technology is available.
We have no doubts that there is going to be some significant cost to such a system. If we consider the cost of just one major disaster, such as happened, luckily without major loss of life in the community of Mississauga a few years ago, or could happen, at any time in any major community in Canada, then the cost of implementing such a system for which technologies are now available fades into insignificance. All we need is one major incident to show us that whatever costs are involved in implementing this kind of system, it would be a bargain for all of us.
In conclusion, we generally support the thrust of the bill. We realize that it goes some way toward improving the current regime. However, we feel that there could be some improvements to ensure that lives can be saved, the environment can be saved, and communities can be saved across Canada. We will be making proposals in committee to that end.

that Bill C-306, an act to amend the Department of Forestry act and to make related amendments to other acts, be read the second time and referred to Legislative Committee D.
He said: Madam Speaker, thank you for giving me this opportunity to lead off the debate on the private member's bill I had the privilege of tabling. As you know, the purpose of this bill is to substitute the name "Department of Forests" for the name "Department of Forestry". It would probably be helpful if I provided a brief outline of the reasons that inspired this legislation.
First of all, as you will no doubt recall, Madam Speaker, in 1989 the government agreed to include a definition of the term "sustainable development" in the terms of reference of the new Department of Forestry. I may point out, in all modesty, that this definition was included as a result of an amendment I tabled in the legislative committee that was examining the legislation.
In fact, the inclusion in the bill of the definition that sustainable development meets the needs of the present without compromising the ability of future generations to meet their own needs is a major step forward for the environment.
The definition gives us the assurance that the Department of Forestry will play a key role in preserving Canada's valuable forests. It also ensures that when federal governments use the term, they will have a clear and precise definition.
Second, in its report entitled Canada's Forests: The Federal Role, the Standing Committee on Forestry and Fisheries emphasized the importance of sustainable development. In its first recommendation, the committee said that the principles of sustainable development and stewardship must be the basis for public policy concerning the management of Canada's forests.
Private Members' Business
In its second recommendation, the committee urged that the new federal Department of Forestry be charged with initiating and developing a process and a structure for the design, planning and implementation of sustainable development in Canada's forests.
In its third recommendation, the committee says, and I quote: "-in the context of its mission and to fully embrace a comprehensive vision of Canada's forest resources, the new Department of Forestry should be renamed the Federal Department of Forests (Forests Canada)".
During the debate on this recommendation, the committee pointed out that the English designation of the new department was considerably removed from its designation in French. You will agree, Madam Speaker, that Forestry Canada has a connotation that is entirely different from "Forets Canada".
Still according to the committee's report, the term forestry was confusing because it did not mean the same thing to everyone. To many environmentalists, the term applies to the lumber industry, while most departmental officials and representatives of the industry feel it covers all forestry operations and the management of these operations.
For instance, one of the witnesses who appeared before the committee, Mr. Mathew Wright, vice-president of the Nova Scotia Forest Products Association, made the point that the word "forestry" seems to focus far more on industrial development than the word "forests", which has a far more general meaning and a much broader connotation.
As you can see, Madam Speaker, the change is necessary because the English and French versions are not identical; because the term forestry is confusing; and because the name of the department should reflect its mandate.

I introduced this bill for reasons related to the forestry subcommittee report tabled in the House in November 1990.
I would like to quote recommendation No. 3:
"The committee recommends that in the context of its mission and to fully embrace a comprehensive vision of

Private Members' Business
Canada's forest resources the new Department of Forestry should be renamed the Federal Department of Forests or Forest Canada".
It goes on to say:
"It should be noted that this change would only be applicable in the English language as the new department is now called Foret Canada in the French language and Bill C-29 is entitled loi sur le ministere des forets. In fact, the English and French names of the department will be closer in meaning as a result of this recommendation. For the purposes of consistency and so as not to anticipate any future decisions-", and the report goes on to say that it will use the name Forestry Canada for now.
The report was signed by all parties, all members of that committee. The chairman of that committee, the hon. member for Fredericton-York-Sunbury, signed it, as did the members for Cochrane-Superior, Prince George-Bulkley Valley, Cariboo-Chilcotin, Bonaven-ture-fles-de-la-Madeleine, and Elgin-Norfolk. It was supported at that time by those individuals.
The second report of the Standing Committee on Forestry and Fisheries recommended that change in the context of the mission of the Department of Forestry and said that it should be renamed the Department of Forests.
The new Department of Forestry Act contains the words: "sustainable development". Accordingly, the name of the department to which it applies should reflect that principle. According to the second report of the standing committee on forests there exists widespread misunderstanding about the word "forestry" and the values which it reflects. For many people the word denotes only commercial forest exploitation, therefore it was felt that "forests" would be a more appropriate and accurate term.
Finally, the English and French names of the department are not consistent. In French the name ministere des Forets translates as Department of Forests. I am certain that members will agree that the English and French names of a department should convey the same meaning to avoid confusion.
Another reason I am interested in this issue is because of the sustainable development issue, which the new department is beginning to address. I tabled an amendment in committee concerning sustainable development which now forms part of the act. I am very proud of that. I am also very proud that the amendment was again supported by all parties. That shows the co-operation in the House on non-partisan issues especially.
Basically the name change is put in there because of my interest in sustainable development and because of the mission that the department now has. It is also because of the language difference between the French and English versions.
In conclusion, I would like to thank the seconder of the bill today-

I wish to thank the hon. member for Champlain for his support today.

I would also like to note the support of the minister for this bill. I would like to note the support of members from all parties. Without mentioning names and whatever, I would like to say that I have received a lot of encouragement and a lot of support and I suppose a real honourable mention to-

-to the hon. member for Champlain for his co-operation in preparing the debate today.

I believe later we will find that there could be unanimous consent to move this directly to the standing committee and we will probably make that commitment later on. The intention is to get it to committee with the idea that the bill be amended somewhat to reflect some of the discussions that we have had to make sure that the implementation is cost-effective, not to change the name overnight because that has certain cost implications and we are willing to abide by that.
I would again thank all the members and my colleagues here this afternoon for their anticipated support.

speakeroldname: Mr. Michel Champagne (Parliamentary Secretary to Minister of Forestry):
speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of Forestry
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, I am also very pleased to speak for a few moments on Bill C-306, whose purpose is to change the name of Forestry Canada to Forests Canada. This bill was presented by my colleague, the hon. member for Restigouche-Chaleur.
I am even more pleased to support this bill, because it is fully in keeping with the recommendations of the Sub-Committee on Forestry published in 1990 that the hon. member for Restigouche-Chaleur had in his hand. This bill, as you know, proposes to change the English name "Forestry Canada" to "Forests Canada". After discussing it at length with our caucus and the minister, we concluded that the bill was very appropriate and that we should follow it up, of course, with all the reservations that my colleague from Restigouche-Chaleur mentioned.
Changing the department's name, minor though the change is, is important. You know, Madam Speaker, that it is being done for some essential reasons. First of all, this change fits in with the department's changing role. In addition, it reflects the new emphasis that the federal government places on forest management as part of sustainable development. Finally, it expresses the growing popularity in Canada of using our forests for many purposes.
On the first point, the role of the department has changed considerably since it was created in 1960.
Originally the department concentrated on supporting the forest industry and the provinces that conducted research and implemented joint forest development programs. However, in the last few years the government has expanded the mandate of the department in order to put more emphasis on dialogue between the various forest interest groups in Canada.
We need only look at some of the recent laudable efforts made by the department and the minister to see
Private Members' Business
how Forestry Canada has succeeded in playing this valuable role.
For example, last year the minister, through the department, organized a successful parliamentary conference on Canada's forestry resources. This event brought competing interests to the same table to discuss the future of forest resources in Canada.
The government also co-operated with the provinces and industry, as well as with environmentalists, nature lovers and others, to develop the national strategy on forests.
Lately, the department has shown that, at a time when the future of our forests is hotly debated, it has done more and more to facilitate dialogue in order to find realistic solutions. The department has approached both complementary and competing groups within the government and industry and among environmental groups. We very much want to bring all those stakeholders together.
It is therefore appropriate that the department be renamed Forests Canada. The new designation will reflect the expanded perspective in which we now view the central role of the federal government in the field of forestry. Also, the name Forests Canada puts the focus of our action more clearly on the forests and therefore more accurately reflects the federal government's priorities and concerns.

The new name also makes sense as it provides the department with an opportunity to more clearly exemplify the federal approach to our forests.
We all recognize the critical importance of Canada's forests. They are one of our greatest natural resources. They are of immense importance to Canada as a nation and they are undoubtedly becoming a resource which is of ongoing interest to the world.
Canada's forests cover 10 per cent of the world's forested area. With growing concerns about the viability of the forest industry and the increasing concern about climate change and threats to bio-diversity, Canada's forest management practices are followed with keen interest, both at home and abroad.

The government, through the department, is defining its policy approach in this new, more national and indeed, more global context.

That is why the federal government participates more actively in the development and promotion of sustainable development strategies.
Madam Speaker, we know that the government has taken measures in that direction. The department, through its contribution to the green plan, will lead the way by implementing strategies based on the sustainable development of Canadian forests.
Moreover, the department strives to support Canadian participation in the development of international policies and conventions on sustainable development, including the Conference on the Environment and Development that will be held in Rio next June.
Under the name Forests Canada, the department will be able to relate the policies for the sustainable development of our forests to a national objective and, more generally, to act as a national leader in the management of our forests.
I believe the new name would put the department more in line with the new principles guiding forest management, such as multiple use and sustainable development.
Finally, the new name makes sense in that it reflects a growing movement in Canada advocating the use of our forests for a wide range of purposes, as well as the development of those forests in accordance with a whole series of values.
Madam Speaker, I want to support the new name of the department. It is a minor change. Yet, as I have tried to show, minor changes must not be neglected, because they can sometimes indicate and impel larger positive changes.
Madam Speaker, I hope that my intervention will have been useful and that we will all be able to contribute in some way to making our forests a living heritage.
In closing, Madam Speaker, I think you will find that there is unanimous consent for the following motion:
